title: 113_hr3013
content: The "Home Protection Act of 2013" may be cited as the short title. Mapping of non-structural flood mitigation features is addressed in the act. Section 100216 of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include areas protected by pumping stations, decertified levees, or non-Federal flood protection measures. Flood control structures are expanded to include pumping stations and non-structural flood mitigation measures. The Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 is amended to include areas protected by pumping stations, decertified levees, or non-Federal flood protection measures. Flood control structures now encompass pumping stations and non-structural flood mitigation measures. Additionally, collaboration with States, local communities, and property owners is required to identify specific areas and measures for flood mitigation. SEC. 3. Amends the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act to include the use of circular wind models for stillwater elevation calculations. SEC. 4. Increases the home improvement fairness threshold from 30 percent to 50 percent. SEC. 5. Construction and restoration of flood protection systems. Amendment to the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 regarding construction or reconstruction of flood protection systems, with changes to criteria for determining progress and exclusion of federal funding consideration. Amendment to the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 allows communities to restore disaccredited flood protection systems without considering federal funding levels. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to allow State and local governments to make payments to cover property insurance premiums. The Administrator will establish regulations for this purpose, ensuring consistency with existing sections. Additionally, appropriate credit for flood control structures is addressed. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to require flood insurance rate maps to accurately reflect the level of protection provided by levee systems and other flood protection measures against 100-year frequency floods. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to require accurate flood insurance rate maps reflecting the protection provided by flood protection systems against 100-year frequency floods. SEC. 8. INTEGRATION OF REVISED LEVEE ANALYSIS AND MAPPING PROCEDURES. The text chunk discusses the conditions under which paragraphs (1) and (2) of section 1307(g) of the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 will not apply to a property until certain criteria are met, such as the publication of an updated flood insurance rate map or the community's decision not to provide necessary data for map updates. The text discusses the requirement to publish an updated flood insurance rate map that reflects the protection provided by flood protection systems. SEC. 9. ALTERNATIVE APPROACH FOR ASSESSING AND PRICING FLOOD RISK. Establish a Bipartisan Task Force on Innovation in Financing Flood Risk in the House of Representatives to compile data on market-based solutions for affordable flood insurance. The Task Force will consult with various stakeholders and experts to explore new rate methodologies and approaches for financing flood risk. The methodologies aim to standardize risks, hazards, and losses for property owners and communities, promoting transparency in Flood Insurance Rate Map development by FEMA. The methodologies aim to introduce unified risk determination, analysis, and valuation for mortgages and housing transactions, integrating financial, actuarial, and engineering approaches into one pricing framework to accurately capture potential losses. Additionally, they aim to granulate risks and offer risk-specific solutions. The curr_chunk discusses risk-specific solutions, transparency indexes, and equitable distribution of catastrophic insurance risk. It also mentions the relationship between flood insurance pricing and structured catastrophe derivatives to reduce financial losses due to floods. The curr_chunk focuses on evaluating options for educating policyholders on risk mitigation, integrating policyholders and capital market participants in the risk-financing process, and incentivizing financial markets and individual market participants to update risk disclosures and actions. The curr_chunk focuses on reporting findings, options, and recommendations to the House of Representatives regarding future flood-risk analysis and risk innovation in pricing within 180 days of the enactment of this Act.
